Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: A New Manufacturing Method for Low Cost High Performance Titanium

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Titanium alloys can be stronger than steel at much lower weight. The greatest barrier to the widespread use of titanium, however, has been its high cost, much of which comes from high processing costs. A new powder metallurgy process called hydrogen sintering has been introduced that can produce titanium components with the capacity to compete with the mechanical properties of standard titanium parts produced by forging, but at a fraction of the cost. This new process is very promising for dramatically reducing the cost of titanium parts and components. Titanium parts can be used in many applications (biomedical, chemical processing, aerospace, etc.), but have particular benefit to the transportation sector. By reducing the weight of vehicles, significant savings in fuel consumption will be realized, as well as associated reductions in emissions. This award supports a comprehensive study of the fundamental underlying metallurgical processes associated with the titanium powder process, and the mechanical properties that can be achieved by varying process parameters.

In this research program, the PIs will systematically study the range of mechanical properties that can be attained by several heat treating options that have already shown the capacity to produce wrought-like microstructures from this novel powder metallurgy approach. Processing parameters will be studied for their effects on phase equilibria in the relevant titanium alloy-hydrogen systems, as well as phase transformations and microstructural evolution as functions of thermal cycles and hydrogen partial pressures, the mechanisms and kinetics of the transformations, and the dependence of mechanical properties, especially the fatigue performance, on the microstructure. By studying these relationships and applying the knowledge gained toward maximizing the strength, ductility and fatigue properties of titanium alloys at substantially lower cost, a major step will be taken toward realizing the full benefit of titanium for industry and society.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated a novel powder metallurgy method called hydrogen sintering and phase transformation (HSPT) for making high-performance Ti alloy. Compared to conventional powder metallurgy approaches, which typically sinter Ti alloy compacts in high vacuum, HSPT sinters Ti powder compacts in a partial hydrogen atmosphere. Hydrogen partial pressure, and thus the hydrogen content in the Ti alloy, is controlled during the sintering and cooling processes. Hydrogen is used as a temporary alloying element to control the phase transformations during cooling, giving rise to the formation of ultra-fine microstructure in the as-sintered state.

One of goals of this project to improve the fundamental understanding of the mechanisms of the microstructure evolution during HSPT processing of Ti-6Al-4V. We found that the mechanisms of the microstructural refinement are the combined effects of the precipitation of fine alpha-Ti and alpha 2-Ti3Al particles within the beta grains, which refine the coarse beta grains during isothermal holding, and the eutectoid transformation of remaining beta into very fine alpha-Ti and delta-TiHx at a low temperature. The alpha 2 phase is a temporary intermediate phase during HSPT. It forms during isothermal holds under partial hydrogen atmosphere, and transforms to alpha during dehydrogenation. It was also found that the dehydrogenation temperature has a strong influence on the final microstructure. The lower dehydrogenation temperature (e.g., 600 C) was shown to produce ultra-fine grained (UFG0 microstructure, which because gradually coarser with increasing dehydrogenation temperature. It was discovered that taking advantage of the dehydrogenation process can create a graded microstructure with a coarse lamellar core and a UFG shell.

The fatigue failure behaviors of Ti-6Al-4V produced by the HSPT process were investigated in this project. We found that competition between failure mechanisms controlled by residual pores versus microstructural features. Contrary to conventional understanding, pores did not act as the fatigue controlling feature in all cases. Rather, a trend was seen in which coarse microstructures were substantially less susceptible to pore-initiated failure in comparison to fine microstructures. Specifically, it was observed that the size of the pore required to cause failure was much larger in coarse microstructures than in fine microstructures with the same volume fraction of porosity. It should be noted that despite the decreased susceptibility to pore-related failure, the coarse microstructures had approximately half the fatigue strength of the fine microstructures due to the propensity to form large microstructural facets. It was also found that relative thick grain boundary (GB) alpha was present in the as-sintered condition as well as the globular and bimodal heat-treated conditions, and the microstructural facets at fatigue failure initiation sites were identified as GB alpha that appears to have fractural along the aligned basal planes. A simple geometric relationship approximating a prior β grain as a truncated octahedron shown that decreasing the prior beta grain size has the most potential to reduce the effective slip length caused by GB alpha. Methods to reduce the prior beta grain size and GB alpha thickness have been identified, which have the potential to reduce the effective slip length by ~55% and should significantly boost fatigue life.

The plastic deformation behavior and evolution of microstructure during hot compression testing were also analyzed for HSPT and vacuum-sintered Ti-6Al-4V. In most cases, the microstructure produced by the HSPT heat treatment exhibited slightly higher peak stress compared to the coarse lamellar microstructure, and displayed greater degrees of flow softening across four temperatures and two strain rates. In the regions of highest deformation, porosity was effectively closed under all conditions. Upon elevated temperature alpha+beta deformation, the HSPT microstructure retains its fine, equiaxed nature, and also evades the formation of grain boundary alpha.


Last Modified: 04/30/2021
Modified by: Pei Sun
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project investigated a novel powder metallurgy method called hydrogen sintering and phase transformation (HSPT) for making high-performance Ti alloy. Compared to conventional powder metallurgy approaches, which typically sinter Ti alloy compacts in high vacuum, HSPT sinters Ti powder compacts in a partial hydrogen atmosphere. Hydrogen partial pressure, and thus the hydrogen content in the Ti alloy, is controlled during the sintering and cooling processes. Hydrogen is used as a temporary alloying element to control the phase transformations during cooling, giving rise to the formation of ultra-fine microstructure in the as-sintered state. One of goals of this project to improve the fundamental understanding of the mechanisms of the microstructure evolution during HSPT processing of Ti-6Al-4V. We found that the mechanisms of the microstructural refinement are the combined effects of the precipitation of fine alpha-Ti and alpha 2-Ti3Al particles within the beta grains, which refine the coarse beta grains during isothermal holding, and the eutectoid transformation of remaining beta into very fine alpha-Ti and delta-TiHx at a low temperature. The alpha 2 phase is a temporary intermediate phase during HSPT. It forms during isothermal holds under partial hydrogen atmosphere, and transforms to alpha during dehydrogenation. It was also found that the dehydrogenation temperature has a strong influence on the final microstructure. The lower dehydrogenation temperature (e.g., 600 C) was shown to produce ultra-fine grained (UFG0 microstructure, which because gradually coarser with increasing dehydrogenation temperature. It was discovered that taking advantage of the dehydrogenation process can create a graded microstructure with a coarse lamellar core and a UFG shell. The fatigue failure behaviors of Ti-6Al-4V produced by the HSPT process were investigated in this project. In the regions of highest deformation, porosity was effectively closed under all conditions. Upon elevated temperature alpha+beta deformation, the HSPT microstructure retains its fine, equiaxed nature, and also evades the formation of grain boundary alpha.
